poem:
Guide Me Home

Bluebird echoes in dawn's shiver—  
bones of pine and oaths of steel.  
Along highways, shadows pivot,  
where white-plastered hands  
mend and break; Darren walks.  
The sky wears history like sunlit dust,  
as steps wrestle through haze—  
Texas earth murmurs beneath  
the weight of dreams and soil.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Attica Locke on the US election: ‘It’s white Americans that have to fix this’ Attica Locke’s Bluebird, Bluebird was published in the early days of Donald Trump’s presidency, and introduced readers to Darren Mathews, a Black Texas Ranger grappling with the demands of law enforcement in a divided society. Locke continued his story in 2019’s Heaven, My Home, and now concludes the prize-winning Highway 59 trilogy with Guide Me Home, in which Darren must confront". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
